summary: Pentagon Papers whistleblower (1971) - Exposed Vietnam War lies, targeted by Nixon Plumbers, charges dismissed due to government misconduct, later revealed nuclear secrets and continued whistleblower advocacy until death (2023)
key_facts: RAND Corporation analyst and Marine Corps veteran
Pentagon Papers leak (1971): 7,000 page classified study of Vietnam War deceptions
New York Times and Washington Post published leaked documents
Nixon administration: Sought to discredit and prosecute Ellsberg
White House Plumbers: E. Howard Hunt unit formed partly to stop leaks after Pentagon Papers
Psychiatrist office break-in (1971): Plumbers burglarized Ellsberg's psychiatrist to find dirt
Trial dismissed (1973): Government misconduct including illegal wiretapping and break-in
Nuclear secrets advocacy: Later revealed classified nuclear war plans, advocated against first-strike
Snowden support: Defended Edward Snowden and Chelsea Manning
Doomsday Machine book (2017): Revealed nuclear war planning secrets from 1960s
Died June 2023: Continued whistleblower advocacy until death
Pattern: Demonstrates how whistleblowers are systematically targeted and criminalized
intelligence_connections: RAND Corporation: Defense think tank with classified access
Pentagon: Pentagon Papers documented Defense Department Vietnam deceptions
CIA: Pentagon Papers revealed CIA activities in Vietnam
Nixon White House: Plumbers unit targeted Ellsberg
E. Howard Hunt: Led Plumbers team that burglarized Ellsberg's psychiatrist
FBI: Conducted illegal wiretapping of Ellsberg
Nuclear command: Ellsberg had access to war plans, revealed decades later
Whistleblower network: Supported Snowden, Manning, other truth-tellers
concealment_mechanisms: Pentagon Papers classification: Government fought publication claiming national security
Prosecution attempt: Espionage Act charges to deter future whistleblowers
Character assassination: Attempted to discredit Ellsberg personally
Psychiatrist break-in: Illegal operation to find damaging information
Wiretapping: FBI illegally monitored Ellsberg communications
Trial dismissal necessary: Government misconduct so egregious judge dismissed case
Nuclear secrets: Ellsberg withheld some documents for decades, revealed later
power_structure: RAND analyst with classified access leaked to newspapers, Nixon administration mobilized FBI/CIA/Plumbers to stop and discredit, Pentagon Papers publication required Supreme Court decision against government censorship, Ellsberg's prosecution failed due to government overreach, established precedent for whistleblower targeting
strategic_significance: Pentagon Papers revealed systematic government lying about Vietnam War - demonstrated that classification often protects political embarrassment not national security, Ellsberg case shows how whistleblowers are criminalized and targeted with illegal operations, trial dismissal established limits on government persecution but not protections for future whistleblowers
